unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: P-value of a 2-Sided Test When Given the t-test Statistic
question_text:
A significance test was performed to test ${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =16$ versus the alternative ${ H }_{ a }:\mu \neq 16$. A random sample of size $51$ produced a test statistic is $t = 1.348$.
Which of the following intervals contains the P-value for this test?
solution:
Since the alternative includes $â‰ $ we are dealing with a 2 sided test meaning we are looking for the sum of the probabilities of $t < -1.348$ and $t >1.348$.

Below is a picture of the data:

Method 1 (easier approach): Using the TI graphing calculator.
In a one sample t-test the degrees of freedom is $n-1$.

In this case, the degrees of freedom is $51-1=50$.

Using the tcdf function (located by hitting 2nd Vars).

Below is the calculator input on the TI-84.
. This will give the P-value for a one-sided test.

2*tcdf(-99999,-1.384,50)=0.1837

Method 1: Solving by using the t-distribution table.

Looking at the t distribution table find 50 degrees of freedom. Using 50 D.OF. go across that row and find the two critical values that $1.348$ fall in between.

$1.348$ falls in between $1.299$ and $1.676$.
Go to the top of those respective columns and see what interval of probability is. The interval of probability is exclusively between $0.05$ and $0.10$.

Since this a 2 sided test we must double those P-values and therefore our P-value will range between but not including $0.10$ and $0.20$.

Since $1.384$ is closer to $1.299$ than $1.677$ we can see our probability will be closer to $0.20$.

~Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'D' is incorrect because more than likely the P-value found was for a one sided test($0.092$). This value should have been doubled since test test was two-sided.

Choice 'C' is incorrect as more than likely the P-value of $0.092$ was divided by $2$ when it should have been doubled.
